title: Stars Reach and Looking in on Homestead Progress
description: The homesteading update that landed two Saturdays ago introduced the concept of the homestead, the ability to take a temporary camp you can lay down and turn it into a permanent property claim… for specific definitions of the word “permanent” here.  Basically it won’t go away until you release it or they wipe the server […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: The homesteading update that landed two Saturdays ago introduced the concept of the homestead, the ability to take a temporary camp you can lay down and turn it into a permanent property claim̷…
text: The homesteading update that landed two Saturdays ago introduced the concept of the homestead, the ability to take a temporary camp you can lay down and turn it into a permanent property claim… for specific definitions of the word “permanent” here.  Basically it won’t go away until you release it or they wipe the server for a new round of tests. Stars Reach As I mentioned last time, I got myself all the way to being able to claim and build on a homestead, and then stopped.  That was in part because I am not much of a builder.  My outposts in Valheim, for example, tended to be the most simple thing beyond a lean-to I could manage.  I am not that patient, that invested, and that interested in running around and collecting all the material.  At least not for myself.  If Potshot is working on a grand design I’ll go harvest in support of that.  I am simply not an enthusiastic patron of my own projects. That and the fact that the tools are still a bit rough and twitchy to use kept me from going too far on that front.  I am more likely to get in trouble elsewhere, left to my own devices. A little roach spray and he’s toast, right? This past Saturday there was a continuation of the ongoing homestead test, with some updates to fix a few issues… and maybe clean up the flood damage that Raph wrote about… and I dropped in towards the end of the test to take a look at progress. The first thing I saw was a few onboarding messages to help new testers figure out what is going on.  One of the classic mistakes of many projects is your core testing group basically learning the system so you forget that somebody new might be totally lost.  The dev team is especially susceptible to this, especially things they learn to work around out of habit because they will “fix that later” only later never comes because they grow so used to the work around behavior that it seems normal.  Some of the most annoying bugs I have seen shipped are ones that everybody knew about but nobody wrote up because they were just there in front of everyone. I actually came back just where I left off last time, next to the fountain on the main strip of the town that was being willed into existence by testers.  From there I backed up to see how things were progressing. Looking at the town layout From there you can see, if you know what you are looking for, almost all the aspects of homesteads.  There are smooth looking building pieces made by the fabricator. A fabricator house The fabricator pieces give you a good looking, modern space building with walls and ramps and windows and floors.  The options are limited… you start seeing a lot of very similar buildings after a bit… but this is pre-alpha and were testing the function not the style. That house is on top of a bunch of blocks placed by the instaformer… as is the wall I am standing on in that image above.  The instaformer will let you take materials from the world, turn them into blocks at the crafting station, then place them in the world.  So if you want a wooden look, you can use that. Wooden building The problem is that those blocks are the Minecraft 2009 standard 1 meter by 1 meter in size… which is kind of big when you’re building something on a human scale.  Good for a lot of foundational work, but it can look primitive next to the fabricator pieces unless blended right. You can also see a couple of homestead patches covered by planted trees.  You cannot harvest those trees… trees on somebody’s homestead… without permission.  I tried.  So there are some basic rules and permissions settings for building now. There is, in that image, a notion of how much space you get with a homestead… or, rather, that you do not just get the surface of the planet but a cube extending into the ground and up into the sky.  So people were digging out foundation areas for basements or bomb shelters. Digging out the homestead fully I am not sure that even the deepest bomb shelter will save you when the devs unleash the meteors.  Also, basements are subject to flooding, just like in the real world.  See the above linked story from Raph, who lives in California so might not know, or might have forgotten, the issues with basements.  (The water table in many coastal areas make deep basements a problem out here.  Also, our tract housing is some of the most cheaply built in the country, and basements cost extra.) There were also people exploring how high their builds could go. Floors up in the air Speaking of things that remind me of Minecraft.  I suspect that physics will be made to intervene in such unsupported structures in the future.  But for now it is part of the test. I went out and found my homestead and released it, removing my claim and my mis-matched attempt to get a simple floor laid out from the world. Claim removal process I wanted to remove it in part to stop mucking up the view.  Even though I was out on the periphery of the evolving town, people had claimed plots near mine and I didn’t want to crowd them or leave an eyesore. And that leads me to something else you can see in that initial image of the town… the environmental destruction.  True to form as humans, we just go harvest stuff wherever it is handy and dump our trash… or tailings in the case… any place we think nobody is looking. Holes in the ground, tailings around Any bit of resources to hand gets torn up. Once a hill, now holes and tailing dumps And tailings, tailings, everywhere. Tailings after dark Granted, the tailings… which are now gravel… did find some use for a couple of people, if voice chat was any indication.  But you can’t haul it (or haul water, for that matter) and most of the time you’re just dumping it next to your dig site where it just sits in clumps. (Except in space, where it was still solid the last time I checked, so you could build with it in a crude fashion.) (Also, I find the day/night cycle a bit oppressive… but I guess I find it so in real life too.  But in Stars Reach it is pretty quick and I was trying to take screen shots and the shadows would literally race by and night would fall.) While on the topic of graphics, I also found the homestead visible boundaries to be a bit of a problem when trying to take screen shots.  When your camera gets too close to them, they are visible. The yellow frame claim boarder flaring up to show this spot is taken If you want to know why so many of my screen shots are wide vistas… that is part of the reason.  I suspect that will need to be a toggle at some point. Now, all of this is being done without the planned planetary governance rules and zoning and other things that are on the list to be done.  At some future date, in a more finished product, you may not be able to dump your tailings next to your neighbors plot or dig up just any bit of landscape to tile the basement of your new homestead, or place homesteads where every you like. But for now we’re in a test and we’re digging stuff up and draining the water and doing all the things we do.  Better to figure that out now, the better to craft the rules for later. Looking at the water having gone down… also, holes And in a test, some amount of chaos is part of the deal. People just doing whatever At some people, location will matter and planets will live or be destroyed based on the governance rules.  Who will get the high ground with the nice view when there is a planetary council? I bet the head of the council will live up there Anyway, it is a test of us as much as a test of the game mechanics at times.  When you give people tools to change things, they will change things. A view of one end of the town area What happens when a wider group, a non-self selected cadre of player, gets access to the tools… well, I bet it will be educational at some level, telling us a lot about ourselves. I will be interested to see how that plays out. Past play test posts for Stars Reach: Sep 17, 2024 – Stars Reach and the Terrain Modification Play Test Oct 7, 2024 – Scenes from a Stars Reach New Tools Play Test Oct 21, 2024 – Stars Reach and Play Testing Combat, Exploration, and Ranger Skills Nov 4, 2024 – Stars Reach Takes its Play Test into Space Nov 18, 2024 – Stars Reach: Jungle World, Desert World, and More Play Test Time Nov 24, 2024 – Stars Reach and Some Weekday Evening Tests Dec 3, 2024 – Stars Reach and the Search for the Instaformer Dec 6, 2024 – Stars Reach and Civil Engineering Coming and Going Dec 11, 2024 – Stars Reach and the Homestead Phase of Pre-Alpha Dec 17, 2024 – Stars Reach and Looking in on Homestead Progress
html:
The homesteading update that landed two Saturdays ago introduced the concept of the homestead, the ability to take a temporary camp you can lay down and turn it into a permanent property claim… for specific definitions of the word “permanent” here.  Basically it won’t go away until you release it or they wipe the server for a new round of tests.

Stars Reach

As I mentioned last time, I got myself all the way to being able to claim and build on a homestead, and then stopped.  That was in part because I am not much of a builder.  My outposts in Valheim, for example, tended to be the most simple thing beyond a lean-to I could manage.  I am not that patient, that invested, and that interested in running around and collecting all the material.  At least not for myself.  If Potshot is working on a grand design I’ll go harvest in support of that.  I am simply not an enthusiastic patron of my own projects.

That and the fact that the tools are still a bit rough and twitchy to use kept me from going too far on that front.  I am more likely to get in trouble elsewhere, left to my own devices.

A little roach spray and he’s toast, right?

This past Saturday there was a continuation of the ongoing homestead test, with some updates to fix a few issues… and maybe clean up the flood damage that Raph wrote about… and I dropped in towards the end of the test to take a look at progress.

The first thing I saw was a few onboarding messages to help new testers figure out what is going on.  One of the classic mistakes of many projects is your core testing group basically learning the system so you forget that somebody new might be totally lost.  The dev team is especially susceptible to this, especially things they learn to work around out of habit because they will “fix that later” only later never comes because they grow so used to the work around behavior that it seems normal.  Some of the most annoying bugs I have seen shipped are ones that everybody knew about but nobody wrote up because they were just there in front of everyone.

I actually came back just where I left off last time, next to the fountain on the main strip of the town that was being willed into existence by testers.  From there I backed up to see how things were progressing.

Looking at the town layout

From there you can see, if you know what you are looking for, almost all the aspects of homesteads.  There are smooth looking building pieces made by the fabricator.

A fabricator house

The fabricator pieces give you a good looking, modern space building with walls and ramps and windows and floors.  The options are limited… you start seeing a lot of very similar buildings after a bit… but this is pre-alpha and were testing the function not the style.

That house is on top of a bunch of blocks placed by the instaformer… as is the wall I am standing on in that image above.  The instaformer will let you take materials from the world, turn them into blocks at the crafting station, then place them in the world.  So if you want a wooden look, you can use that.

Wooden building

The problem is that those blocks are the Minecraft 2009 standard 1 meter by 1 meter in size… which is kind of big when you’re building something on a human scale.  Good for a lot of foundational work, but it can look primitive next to the fabricator pieces unless blended right.

You can also see a couple of homestead patches covered by planted trees.  You cannot harvest those trees… trees on somebody’s homestead… without permission.  I tried.  So there are some basic rules and permissions settings for building now.

There is, in that image, a notion of how much space you get with a homestead… or, rather, that you do not just get the surface of the planet but a cube extending into the ground and up into the sky.  So people were digging out foundation areas for basements or bomb shelters.

Digging out the homestead fully

I am not sure that even the deepest bomb shelter will save you when the devs unleash the meteors.  Also, basements are subject to flooding, just like in the real world.  See the above linked story from Raph, who lives in California so might not know, or might have forgotten, the issues with basements.  (The water table in many coastal areas make deep basements a problem out here.  Also, our tract housing is some of the most cheaply built in the country, and basements cost extra.)

There were also people exploring how high their builds could go.

Floors up in the air

Speaking of things that remind me of Minecraft.  I suspect that physics will be made to intervene in such unsupported structures in the future.  But for now it is part of the test.

I went out and found my homestead and released it, removing my claim and my mis-matched attempt to get a simple floor laid out from the world.

Claim removal process

I wanted to remove it in part to stop mucking up the view.  Even though I was out on the periphery of the evolving town, people had claimed plots near mine and I didn’t want to crowd them or leave an eyesore.

And that leads me to something else you can see in that initial image of the town… the environmental destruction.  True to form as humans, we just go harvest stuff wherever it is handy and dump our trash… or tailings in the case… any place we think nobody is looking.

Holes in the ground, tailings around

Any bit of resources to hand gets torn up.

Once a hill, now holes and tailing dumps

And tailings, tailings, everywhere.

Tailings after dark

Granted, the tailings… which are now gravel… did find some use for a couple of people, if voice chat was any indication.  But you can’t haul it (or haul water, for that matter) and most of the time you’re just dumping it next to your dig site where it just sits in clumps. (Except in space, where it was still solid the last time I checked, so you could build with it in a crude fashion.)

(Also, I find the day/night cycle a bit oppressive… but I guess I find it so in real life too.  But in Stars Reach it is pretty quick and I was trying to take screen shots and the shadows would literally race by and night would fall.)

While on the topic of graphics, I also found the homestead visible boundaries to be a bit of a problem when trying to take screen shots.  When your camera gets too close to them, they are visible.

The yellow frame claim boarder flaring up to show this spot is taken

If you want to know why so many of my screen shots are wide vistas… that is part of the reason.  I suspect that will need to be a toggle at some point.

Now, all of this is being done without the planned planetary governance rules and zoning and other things that are on the list to be done.  At some future date, in a more finished product, you may not be able to dump your tailings next to your neighbors plot or dig up just any bit of landscape to tile the basement of your new homestead, or place homesteads where every you like.

But for now we’re in a test and we’re digging stuff up and draining the water and doing all the things we do.  Better to figure that out now, the better to craft the rules for later.

Looking at the water having gone down… also, holes

And in a test, some amount of chaos is part of the deal.

People just doing whatever

At some people, location will matter and planets will live or be destroyed based on the governance rules.  Who will get the high ground with the nice view when there is a planetary council?

I bet the head of the council will live up there

Anyway, it is a test of us as much as a test of the game mechanics at times.  When you give people tools to change things, they will change things.

A view of one end of the town area

What happens when a wider group, a non-self selected cadre of player, gets access to the tools… well, I bet it will be educational at some level, telling us a lot about ourselves.

I will be interested to see how that plays out.
